doc.previous: Around 6000 B.C., rising seas created the English Channel and separated the Norman promontories that became the bailiwicks of Guernsey and Jersey from continental Europe.[4] Neolithic farmers then settled on its coast and built the dolmens and menhirs found in the islands today.
doc.after: During their migration to Brittany, Britons occupied the Lenur islands (the former name of the Channel Islands[5]) including Sarnia or Lisia (Guernsey) and Angia (Jersey). Travelling from the Kingdom of Gwent, Saint Sampson, later the abbot of Dol in Brittany, is credited with the introduction of Christianity to Guernsey.[6]
